Award.AwardTitle: Identification and Characterization of Matrikines for Cardiac Differentiation and Regeneration

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Black, Lauren D.
Proposal #: 1603524

There is great need for improved materials and techniques that can be used for the treatment of cardiac injury or disease. Investigators have shown that a variety of singular proteins derived from the cardiac extracellular matrix (cECM) promote cardiomyocyte (CM) proliferation or cardiac differentiation of stem cells, but little work has been done to identify the short peptide sequences on those proteins, termed matrikines, that are the active ingredients leading to the altered cellular responses. Based on preliminary data that indicates that cardiac cells respond differently to cECM obtained from fetal compared to adult hearts, the investigators of this 3 year project are going to test the hypothesis that there exists a number of matrikines in the developing heart ECM that could be useful in strategies for cardiac regeneration and repair, via enhancement of CM proliferation and survival and the cardiac differentiation of stem cells. Identification of these matrikines would be significant for understanding the importance of cECM remodeling during cardiac growth as well as for the potential development of therapeutics for the treatment of cardiac injury or disease. Educational impact will be made at the undergraduate and graduate levels through integration of techniques and results in courses and laboratories; impact at the high school level will be made through seminars at local high schools and as part of the Biomedical Engineering department's summer research program for high school students.

The composition of the extracellular matrix (ECM) is a powerful regulator of a number of cellular processes. In the heart, a variety of singular proteins derived from the cardiac ECM (cECM) promote cardiomyocyte (CM) proliferation or cardiac differentiation of stem cells. Most investigations to date have examined only singular ECM proteins as binding sites for the cells, even though the ECM in vivo is a complex mixture of proteins that is organ/ tissue and life stage specific. Furthermore, the emphasis has been on singular proteins rather than on the short peptide segments/matrkines that are likely to be the bioactive region leading to altered cellular responses. The investigators' lab has shown that cECM derived from fetal hearts promotes cardiomyocyte proliferation as compared to ECM derived from adult hearts and that cardiac progenitor cells have altered differentiation responses to cECM derived from different developmental stages. Thus, the goal of this project is to test the hypothesis that there exists a number of matrikines in the developing heart ECM that could be useful in strategies for cardiac regeneration and repair, via enhancement of CM proliferation and survival and the cardiac differentiation of stem cells. The hypothesis will be tested by carrying out two aims: 1) Identify and characterize matrikines derived from fetal and adult cECM (pigs at 3rd trimester and 3-6 months) that promote induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) differentiation to cardiac cells and/or enhance proliferation or maturation of iPSC-derived CMs (iPSC-CMs) and 2) Assess the efficacy of the matrikines derived from cECM in promoting human iPSC-CM survival, proliferation and function in 3-D engineered cardiac tissue models of healthy and diseased myocardium. Identification of these matrikines would be significant for understanding the importance of cECM remodeling during cardiac growth as well as for the potential development of therapeutics for the treatment of cardiac injury or disease. Educational impact will be made at the undergraduate and graduate levels through integration of techniques and results in courses and laboratories; impact at the high school level will be made through seminars at local high schools and as part of the BME department's summer research program for high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes that address the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the work:

The goal of this project was to determine whether there are fragments of the extracellular matrix (ECM) that are formed upon breakdown of the structure by proteases that signal to cardiac cells and promote their differentiation, proliferation and/ maturation during development. We also wanted to see if the delivery of these matrix fragments, called matrikines, could impact the health of cardiac cells in an in vitro model of injury that is designed to simulate a myocardial infarction, or heart attack. To do this we first isolated ECM from hearts at different stages during development of the rat (fetal and adult) and characterized the proteins that were present in the structure at those ages. We then digested the ECMs using enzymes and fractionated the digests to generate groupings of peptides that were similar in molecular weight. These fractions were then used to treat pluripotent stem cells during and after the differentiation process to cardiac muscle cells, or cardiomyocytes (CMs). We found that some fractions enhanced the differentiation process while others inhibited it. In terms of the effects on already differentiated cardiac cells we were able to identify peptides that promoted proliferation of these cells. We also demonstrated that these different ECM types had an effect on the main cell type that supports CMs in the heart tissue: cardiac fibroblasts (CFs). In particular, the adult ECM promoted a more migratory phonotype from CFs when activated.

In a second set of experiments we attempted to create a model of the injury that occurs during the blockage of a coronary artery. In our case we sought to use a metal probe that had been cooled to very low temperatures by immersing it in liquid nitrogen and then applying this probe to the surface of a hydrogel system that contained the ECM. We had some initial difficulties getting this system to work, but were finally able to demonstrate a model that was successful where we could induce a local injury that led to the death of the cardiac cells in contact with the probe but still had living cells surrounding the injured area.  

In terms of the Broader Impacts outcomes of this proposal there are two key ones to report on. The first is that over 30 high school students were trained in laboratory research techniques and exposed to Biomedical Engineering as part of the high school summer research program proposed in this grant. These students have gone on to college, many have majored in Biology or Biomedical Engineering and most have continued in doing research as they reach the collegiate level. The other major outcome is that several modules were developed for course teaching both undergraduate and graduate students at Tufts University, including lectures in a Physiology course, an Introduction to BME course and a Tissue Engineering Course. 

Other products that have resulted from the grant: 

Beyond the abstracts and conference proceedings already published related to this work, several other products have been generated. These include: 1) several posters presented at conferences related to the project, 2) several posters generated by high school students participating in the outreach program, 3) survey data related to the high school program and its effectiveness, and 4) lectures related to the research for a variety of classes at Tufts in the Biomedical Engineering department as well as seminars for visits at other universities. 

Anticipated publication of remaining project results:

While we have not published a manuscript related to this project to date we anticipate at least six manuscripts to be submitted for publication in the next 6-9 months that were at least partially funded by this award. These include: 1) a manuscript related to a specific peptide that promotes cardiac muscle cell proliferation, 2) a manuscript related to the effects of different aged ECM on cardiac cells’ ability to contract, 3) a manuscript on the differences in CFs with developmental age, 4) a manuscript on the different ECM produced by CFs as a function of developmental age, 5) a manuscript on the peptides formed when ECM is digested by specific enzymes called matrix metalloproteases and 6) a manuscript detailing the method for generating the in vitro model of cardiac injury.
